channel.title: Iterating case Statements

item.title: Iterating case Statements
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“The Outsider, post:34, topic:425695”]^That’s fine. As you can tell I simply wanted to save myself from typing out 30 different numbers and use the “case i:” as a substitute for a long stack of numbers. Simply for time consumption convenience. And to see if it could be done at all.

The binary I don’t really understand (in terms of using it within Java) so I won’t be using any tables as aforementioned, but very interesting on how you can use the raw machine code inside your Java methods and variables like that.[/quote]

That’s not what was meant by binary.

The idea of binary sorting is pretty simple. Based on some comparator factor (in this case, just the integer values you’re using in the switch statement), values are sorted from weakest to greatest (or lowest to highest, depending on how you perceive it).

Now, when you want to look through that array to get the index of a value inside it, you can use a simple function like this:

public int getIndex(int needle, int[] haystack) {
	for (int i = 0; i < haystack.length; i++)
		if (haystack[i] == needle)
			return i;
	return -1;
}

However, this method is conventionally slow when searching an array which is binary sorted, because there are faster ways of searching it. This particular method is of O(n) complexity, meaning it’s linear and is processed n number of needed times. A search will always take between 1 and n (array length) operations to find the index.

With binary, the search algorithm should always take at least half, or less, of the time a linear search would require. I’ll briefly explain why. Binary search algorithms would typically start in the middle of the array, instead of at the beginning with a linear array. If the value is equal to that middle index, great! Otherwise, the algorithm can check if the value is greater or lower, and thereby know whether to go forward or back in the array to search for the value. It’s called binary searching because it always segments the array by 2 (starts off with two halves, selects one and divides it into two again, and so on). It continues this process until it finds a match, or finds where a match ought to be, and returns a negative form of it (or -1, for some implementations).

I’d recommend reading up on it, or looking through [tt]java.util.Arrays.sort()[/tt] and [tt]java.util.Arrays.binarySearch[/tt]. There is also bubble sorting or sequential sorting, as mentioned above, among other more complex strategies. Binary is really basic and powerful for what it achieves, though.

Read full topic

item.title: Iterating case Statements
item.dc:creator: @Pure_Slay Pure Slay
item.description:
@Pure_Slay wrote:

I hope case i was an example of more than one solution, or else your code is beyond pointless. Since every value is ‘i’ since it is your accumulator, it doesn’t matter if you use a case statement or not.

for(int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) {
//Whatever it does each loop
}

I believe you are most likely asking for particular values of i, do something.

for(int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) {
if(i == 10) {
//Do something
}
}

Although, if you are trying to do it for particular values, and want to use case structure.

for(int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) {
			switch(i) {
			case 50:
				//Do something here
				break;
				default:
					//NOTHING ?
			}
		}

Although your general concept is pointless, as why would you need to use a case structure unless you are dealing with so many different values that an if statement would be redundant. If you are sorting values, look into binary sorting, sequential sorting, or bubble sort.

EDIT:
Wow, didn’t even show the second page so if my answer seems off, it is because I didn’t see the other 50% of the conversation…

Read full topic

item.title: Iterating case Statements
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“object, post:31, topic:425695”]Or, you could do something like the following:

pKiller.addDragons(Arrays.binarySearch(ARRAY_WITH_DRAGON_IDS, n.getDefinition().getId()) >= 0 ? 1 : 0);

This assumes you store all the dragon IDs in the array (sorted with the lowest first) - and that no side-effects occur if you add the number 0 in the method.

You can achieve the same goal with a List using Collections.binarySearch(…), or, similar to what Taharok said, via a Map.[/quote]

Yes, I’d agree with using a binary-sorted lookup table if you would use a table at all. But even so, I still think what you’re doing now is slightly more efficient (but hell, this is the old memory versus processing debate, so whatever). The best advice I can give is if you are intending to add more cases, it may be wiser to simply use a lookup table, for programming convenience.

And in all honesty, even the bytecode which is created from the switch code uses an internal lookup table anyway, which is probably of linear complexity, so a binary-sorted lookup table would be theoretically faster.

Read full topic

item.title: Iterating case Statements
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Or, you could do something like the following:

pKiller.addDragons(Arrays.binarySearch(ARRAY_WITH_DRAGON_IDS, n.getDefinition().getId()) >= 0 ? 1 : 0);

This assumes you store all the dragon IDs in the array (sorted with the lowest first) - and that no side-effects occur if you add the number 0 in the method.

You can achieve the same goal with a List using Collections.binarySearch(…), or, similar to what Taharok said, via a Map.

Read full topic

item.title: Iterating case Statements
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

The only way you’re going to be able to compact that is using an if statement, or just moving the cases to a few lines, rather than one line for each case (I’d prefer doing this).

What you have is logically correct. Using a switch in this context is also not going to be much faster than using an if statement, but it’s considered to be better programming practice because you are comparing a single variable to multiple constants.

I do realize not being able to do ranges in a switch statement is rather limiting, but there’s not much you can do about that. Another way would be to use a lookup table, but seeing as that involves additional memory, it’s probably not worth it.

Read full topic

Other than that… I tend to use arrays, but as I said I was already in a switch, so wanted to know my limitations.

Read full topic

item.title: Iterating case Statements
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Iterating through constants is completely possible, but like I pointed out you still need to SPECIFY those constants somewhere. And then once you have them specified, using a switch statement is completely pointless, because as you’re checking one value at a time that way, an if statement is better.

Read full topic

item.title: Iterating case Statements
item.dc:creator: @The_Outsider The Outsider
item.description:
@The_Outsider wrote:

Lol, certainly.

I’ll post the code that I have:

public DeathEvent(Entity entity) {
		super(4000);
		this.entity = entity;
	}

	@Override
	public void execute() {
		if(entity instanceof Player) {
			Player p = (Player) entity;
			resetPlayer(p);
			p.getActionSender().sendMessage("Oh dear, you are dead!");
			p.addDeaths(1);
			p.getActionSender().sendMessage("You have now died " + p.DEATHS + " times.");
			p.removePrestige(p.getSkills().getCombatLevel());
			if(!p.getFightCaves().exitCaves()) {
				p.setTeleportTarget(Location.create((int) (Entity.DEFAULT_LOCATION.getX() + (Math.random() * 7)), (int) (Entity.DEFAULT_LOCATION.getY() + (Math.random() * 7)), Entity.DEFAULT_LOCATION.getZ()));
				p.dropLoot();
				p.getSkulls().skullId = -1;
				p.getSkulls().skullTimer = 0;
				p.getSkulls().combatInteractions.clear();
				p.getUpdateFlags().flag(UpdateFlag.APPEARANCE);
			}
			p.clearKillersHits();
		} else {
			final NPC n = (NPC) entity;
			final Location goodPos = n.getLocation().getActualLocation(n.getDefinition().getSize());
			final Entity killer = n.getKiller();
			n.clearKillersHits();
			if(killer != null && killer instanceof Player) {
				Player pKiller = (Player) killer;
				if(n.getLocation().isInBarrows()) {
					pKiller.getBarrows().increaseKillCount();
				}
				if(pKiller.getSlayerTask().hasTask()) {
					for(int task : pKiller.getSlayerTask().getSlayerNpcs()) {
						if(task == n.getDefinition().getId()) {
							pKiller.getSlayerTask().decrementCount();
							pKiller.getSkills().addExperience(Skills.SLAYER, n.getMaxHitpoints());
						}
					}
				}
				switch(n.getDefinition().getId()) {
				/*Dragons*/
				case 50:
				case 51:
				case 52:
				case 53:
				case 54:
				case 55:
				case 742:
				case 941:
				case 1589:
				case 1590:
				case 1591:
				case 1592:
				case 2642:
				case 3376:
				case 3588:
				case 3590:
				case 4665:
				case 4666:
				case 4667:
				case 4668:
				case 4669:
				case 4670:
				case 4671:
				case 4672:
				case 4673:
				case 4674:
				case 4675:
				case 4676:
				case 4677:
				case 4678:
				case 4679:
				case 4680:
				case 4681:
				case 4682:
				case 4683:
				case 4684:
					pKiller.addDragons(1);
					break;
				
				/*
				 * Cyclopes from Warriors Guild.
				 */
				case 4291:
				case 4292:
					pKiller.getWarriorsGuild().killedCyclop(goodPos);
					break;
				}
			}
			n.setInvisible(true);
			NPCDropController drops = NPCDropController.forId(n.getDefinition().getId());
			if(drops != null) {
				for(Item item : drops.getDrops()) {
					if(item != null) {
						GroundItemController.createGroundItem(item, n.getKiller(), goodPos);
					}
				}
			}
			World.getWorld().submit(new Event(n.getDefinition().getRespawn() * 1000) {

				@Override
				public void execute() {
					n.setInvisible(false);
					n.setAutoRetaliating(true);
					n.setHitpoints(n.getMaxHitpoints());
					entity.setTeleportTarget(n.getLocation());
					entity.setDead(false);
					entity.playAnimation(RESET);
					entity.setCanWalk(true);
					this.stop();
				}
				
			});
		}
		this.stop();
	}

This is the DeathEvent class. It’s handled by Entity so the switch statement (eyeownyew) is for switching from the player’s death event to an NPCs death event.

Instead of the long line of Dragon IDs I simply want to use case i: as a way of shortening down this:

/*Dragons*/
				case 50:
				case 51:
				case 52:
				case 53:
				case 54:
				case 55:
				case 742:
				case 941:
				case 1589:
				case 1590:
				case 1591:
				case 1592:
				case 2642:
				case 3376:
				case 3588:
				case 3590:
				case 4665:
				case 4666:
				case 4667:
				case 4668:
				case 4669:
				case 4670:
				case 4671:
				case 4672:
				case 4673:
				case 4674:
				case 4675:
				case 4676:
				case 4677:
				case 4678:
				case 4679:
				case 4680:
				case 4681:
				case 4682:
				case 4683:
				case 4684:
					pKiller.addDragons(1);
					break;

I just wanted it to look tidier.

So the number ID “50” for case 50: is a constant, not an actual integer that can be manipulated in such a way as using a for loop to simply iterate through a range of case constants to shorten the length of the class file?

Read full topic

item.title: Iterating case Statements
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:24, topic:425695”][quote author=The Outsider link=topic=528351.msg3855278#msg3855278 date=1324314772]
No, because I’m stacking case statements for all to be used on one variable. All my case statements IDs are dragons, and upon death it += 1 to the dragon’s killed statistic on my server.

Instead of typing each dragon ID I was hoping I could just use case i: to represent a range of case IDs. Of course I know how to use it in other instances, but since I was already in a switch statement and had over 25 cases to add for one thing, I was wondering if a for loop would work for the case number.
[/quote]
Why do you even need a switch for the loop? You can just check the value inside the loop, or if you don’t even need to have a switch statement (which it seems)… Remove it (common sense)…?[/quote]

This.

The Outsider: You are mixing two different concepts. Loops are used to perform dynamic actions over an amount of iterations. Switches are meant for static checking. [tt]case i:[/tt] makes no sense, because a switch is designed to statically compare a value.

Could you explain what you are trying to do in greater detail. I am still rather confused about it, but I think I have an idea. A little more explanation will help.

Read full topic

Instead of typing each dragon ID I was hoping I could just use case i: to represent a range of case IDs. Of course I know how to use it in other instances, but since I was already in a switch statement and had over 25 cases to add for one thing, I was wondering if a for loop would work for the case number.[/quote]
Why do you even need a switch for the loop? You can just check the value inside the loop, or if you don’t even need to have a switch statement (which it seems)… Remove it (common sense)…?

item.title: Iterating case Statements
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“The Outsider, post:21, topic:425695”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=528351.msg3855100#msg3855100 date=1324279019]
What are you even trying to accomplish with this…?

switch(i) {
case i:
break;
}

seems… EXTREMELY f***ing redundant.
[/quote]
Obviously what I wanted to achieve was less lines of code, and was curious if what I posted was do-able.[/quote]

Unless I am terribly misunderstood, you are actually adding more lines of code.

This is my understanding of what you are trying to achieve:

for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { switch (i) { case 0: System.out.println("I have a zero"); break; case 1: System.out.println("I have a one"); break; case 2: System.out.println("I have a two"); break; case 3: System.out.println("I have a three"); break; case 4: System.out.println("I have a four"); break; } }

When the original code is this:

System.out.println("I have a zero");
System.out.println("I have a one");
System.out.println("I have a two");
System.out.println("I have a three");
System.out.println("I have a four");

You are adding lines of code (meaning more instructions and, thereby, more cpu time). For my given example, you can use constants to try and save space in terms of iterative processing. Here’s how I would try and approach my above example:

private static final String[] numbers = new String[] { "zero", "one", "two", "three", "four" };

public void printNumbers() {
	for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++)
		System.out.printf("I have a %s\n", numbers[i]);
}

Reminding you that, for all purposes other than demonstration, the above would actually be poor implementation.

Read full topic
